title: Onomatopoeias 2
sentences: The flag was fluttering proudly in the wind.
Something was rustling/scuttling quietly in the attic.
The firework made a huge pop/bang in the sky.
A sárban való járáskor a cipőnk
When walking in the mud, our shoes made a splashing/slapping sound.
The distant lightning suddenly flashed in the night.
The little boy was making banging/popping noises with his toys in the room.
The raindrops were tapping on the windowpane.
His side was twitching/shaking from laughter.
The water was boiling/bubbling in the pot.
Someone was murmuring/muttering quietly in the crowd.
The sheets of paper were rustling/fizzing in the draft.
The horses were neighing in the pen.
The wolves were howling in the moonlight.
The soles of our shoes shuffled on the stony road.
The huge machine thundered/rumbled in the factory.
The little girl gave a whistle to her dog.
The bird's wings whished/rustled in the air.
The hot oil was sizzling in the pan.
The frogs were croaking on the lakeshore.
The heavy door closed with a jolt/thud.
The child was sniffing after crying.
The engine was chugging/puffing quietly in the garage.
The audience clapped at the end of the performance.
The wind was rattling the dry leaves.
The splashing/babbling of the brook had a calming effect on him.
dictionary:
lobog - to flutter / flare
motoszkál - to rustle / scuttle / move quietly
pukkan - to pop / bang
paskol - to slap / splash (liquid surface)
villan - to flash
durrog - to bang / pop repeatedly
kopog - to knock / tap
rángatózik - to twitch / jerk
bugyog - to bubble / gush
mormog - to murmur / mutter
zizeg - to rustle (paper/leaves)
nyerít - to neigh
vonyít - to howl
csoszog - to shuffle (feet)
dübörög - to thunder / rumble
füttyent - to whistle (briefly)
suhog - to whish / rustle (movement through air)
serceg - to sizzle
kuruttyol - to croak (frogs)
döccen - to jolt / thud
szipog - to sniff / sob quietly
pöfög - to puff / chug
tapsol - to clap
zörget - to rattle / knock
csobogás - babbling / splashing (of water)
